questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presented with progressive diminution of vision, headache and unsteadiness of gait. A detailed study showed left beating nystagmus with leftward gaze and a fine primary position right beating nystagmus which is consistent with Bruns nystagmus. What is most likely the cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cerebello pontine angle tumour Bruns nystagmus is an unusual type of bilateral nystagmus most commonly occurring in patients with cerebellopontine angle tumours . It is caused by the combination of slow, large-amplitude nystagmus (gaze paretic nystagmus) when looking towards the side of the lesion , and rapid, small-amplitude nystagmus (vestibular nystagmus) when looking away from the side of the lesion.

Highyeild:

Brun's nystagmus . Tumours in the cerebellopontine angle, produce a low-frequency, large-amplitude nystagmus when the patient looks towards the side of the lesion, and high-frequency, small-amplitude nystagmus when the patient looks toward the side opposite to the lesion. The nystagmus that occurs on gaze towards the side of the lesion is gaze-evoked nystagmus caused by defective gaze holding, whereas the nystagmus that occurs during gaze towards the side opposite the lesion is caused by vestibular imbalance. This is called Brun's nystagmus.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Cerebellar lesions and Arnold Chiari malformation: downbeat nystagmus. Options: C and D . Arnold-Chiari malformation and demyelination syndromes: periodic alternating nystagmus.

questions.text: Rakhi was asked by the senior resident of the ophthalmology department to tell, which of the following is not nystagmoid movement.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Optokinetic All are nystagmic movements except optokinetic. Optokinetic nystagmus is a physiological nystagmus.

Highyeild:

PHYSIOLOGICAL NYSTAGMUS: Physiological nystagmus occurs normally in a variety of situations including optokinetic nystagmus (OKN), end gaze nystagmus (EGN) and physiological vestibular nystagmus (vestibulo-ocular reflex, i.e. VOR) Optokinetic nystagmus . It is a physiological jerk nystagmus induced by presenting to gaze the objects moving serially in one direction, such as strips of a spinning optokinetic drum. The eyes will follow a fixed strip momentarily and then jerk back to reposition centrally to fix up a new strip. A similar condition occurs while looking at outside things from a moving train. End-gaze nystagmus . It is a fine jerk horizontal nystagmus seen in normal persons on extreme right or left gaze. Physiological vestibular nystagmus (vestibular-ocular reflex, i.e. VOH) . 1t is a jerk nystagmus which can be elicited by stimulating the tympanic membrane with hot or cold water. It forms the basis of a caloric test. If cold water is poured into the right ear the patient develops left jerk nystagmus (rapid phase cowards left), while the reverse happens with warm water, i.e. patient develops right jerk nystagmus. it can be remembered by the mnemonic 'COWS' (Cold - Opposite, Warm-Same).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Nystagmoid movements: Option: A . Ocular flutter -Ocular flutter is a rare oculomotor syndrome that is clinically defined by intermittent bursts of involuntary conjugate eye oscillations with a strict preponderance for the horizontal plane and without intersaccadic interval. Option: B . Ocular bobbing - Ocular bobbing is characterized by spontaneous downward deviations of the eyes that occur in patients with advanced pontine disease. In the present report, four cases of bobbing are described. The location and extent of the brain stem lesion were different in each case. Option: C . Opsoclonus - Opsoclonus is an oculomotor dyskinesia characterized by rapid, repetitive conjugate eye movements that are involuntary, arrhythmic, chaotic, and multidirectional (horizontal, vertical, and torsional components) without intersaccadic interval.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of CEMAS criteria for Infantile nystagmus syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Head posture usually evident by 4 years of age

options.label: C
options.text: Waveform may change in early infancy

options.label: D
options.text: Vision prognosis dependent on the integrity of the sensory system

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Juvenile onset Early onset (childhood) Nystagmus Three most common forms of nystagmus seen in childhood begin in infancy and therefore, are not congenital as believed earlier. These include • infantile nystagmus syndrome, Fusion maldevelopment nystagmus syndrome, and Spasmus nu tans syndrome.

Highyeild:

Infantile nystagmus syndrome is the new name given in the CEMAS system for the old congenital, motor and sensory nystagmus. Etiology . It may be (I) Idiopathic or (II) Associated with sensory deprivation due to any of the following causes: • Ocular albinism, • Aniridia, • Leber's congenital amaurosis, and • Other causes which include, bilateral congenital cataract, achromatopsia, congenital stationary night blindness, bilateral optic nerve hypoplasia, bilateral congenital toxoplasmosis and bilateral macular hypoplasia. Characteristic features . It is characterized by erratic waveform with or without roving eye movements associated with reduced visual acuity due to the above-mentioned conditions. CEMAS criteria for INS include • infantile-onset, Ocular motor recordings show accelerating slow phases (diagnostic) Waveforms may change in early infancy, Head posture is usually evident by 4 years of age. Vision prognosis depends on the integrity of the sensory system. Common associated findings . • Progression from pendular to jerk, Family history is often positive, and May decrease with induced convergence, increased fusion, extraocular muscle surgery, contact lenses, and sedation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Head posture usually evident by 4 years of age Option: C. Waveform may change in early infancy Option: D. Vision prognosis dependent on the integrity of the sensory system

questions.text: During the evaluation of the eye movement of two patients, you found that patient A- has slow movement followed by slow movement while patient B has slow movement followed by fast movement. Which of the following statements correctly describes the type of nystagmus described?

options.label: A
options.text: Patient A is having a jerk while in patient B the nystagmus is pendular

options.label: B
options.text: Patient A has pendular nystagmus and patient B has a jerk.

questions.correct_answer: B. Patient A has pendular nystagmus and patient B has a jerk.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Patient A has pendular nystagmus and patient B has a jerk. In the given question, patient A is having a slow phase followed by a slow phase which occurs in the case of pendular nystagmus. In patient B, the slow component of nystagmus was followed by the fast This phenomenon is known as a jerk. Hence the correct option is B.

Highyeild:

Nystagmus is defined as regular and rhythmic to-and-fro involuntary oscillatory movements of the eyes. It may be characterised by any of the following features: Waveform : Pendular or jerk nystagmus. In pendular nystagmus, movements are of equal velocity in each direction. It may be horizontal, vertical or rotatory. In jerk nystagmus , the movements have a slow component in one direction (defoveating movement, i.e. the movement that moves the fovea away from the object and a fast component in another direction (refoveating saccadic movement), i.e. the refixation movement that brings the object of interest back at fovea in the other direction. The direction of jerk nystagmus is defined by the direction of the fast component (phase). It may be right, left, up, down or rotatory. Direction of nystagmus may be horizontal, vertical, rotatory, torsional, oblique or a combination of these. Amplitude of nystagmus may be small, medium or large. Rate or frequency of nystagmus may be fast (rapid), or slow. Generally speaking faster the rate, the smaller the amplitude and vice versa. Conjugacy Nystagmus may be conjugate (symmetrical in both eyes), disconjugate (in different directions and different frequencies in two eyes) or dissociative ( unidirectional but asymmetrical). Manifest (present all the time) or latent (present only when one eye is covered). Nystagmus : Rapid rhythmic repetitive involuntary (uncontrollable) eye movements. Nystagmus can be horizontal, vertical or rotary and can effect one or both eyes. This is caused by abnormal function in the area of the brain that controls eye movement. Forms of the Disease Infantile or congenital: Most common and usually present at birth. It can be inherited or associated with a sensory deficit which in turn is most likely responsible for the greater part of vision loss. People affected are not aware of their rapid eye movements but instead are observed by others. Acquired Nystagmus: There are several causes that lead to juvenile and adult onset of nystagmus... Inner ear disorders (labyrinthitis or Meniere's disease) Toxic-drugs, medication (such as antiseizure medications and sedating meds), alcohol intoxication Head injury Stroke (blood vessel blockage in the brain) Diseases of the brain....multiple sclerosis or brain tumors Treatments and Modifications: Movements of large magnitude may require surgery to improve visual acuity. Contacts or glasses can be worn to reduce Congenital nystagmus. Avoid emotional strain, such as stress, tiredness or nervousness. Angle of vision is important, eye muscle surgery may improve the head position and allow for better vision. In most cases, nystagmus is irreversible, except those caused by medication or alcohol

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Patient A is having jerk while in patient B the nystagmus is pendular - This is not the true statement Option: C. Both the patients have jerk nystagmus - This is not the true statement Option: D. Both the patients have pendular nystagmus. - This is not the true statement

questions.text: You were evaluating a 25-year-old male who complained of nausea and vomiting, spinning his head for a duration of 20 sec when he woke up from his bed after sleeping. During the evaluation of the nystagmus of the patient, it was seen that the slow phase was towards the right direction and the fast phase was towards the left side. What will you comment upon the direction of the nystagmus?

options.label: A
options.text: The direction is to the right side as the slow component is towards the right.

options.label: B
options.text: The direction of the nystagmus is to the left side as the direction of the fast component is towards the left side.

questions.correct_answer: B. The direction of the nystagmus is to the left side as the direction of the fast component is towards the left side.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The direction of the nystagmus is to the left side as the direction of the fast component is towards the left side. In the given question, as described the direction of the nystagmus as the slow phase was towards the right direction and the fast phase towards the left side. Hence the direction of the nystagmus is given by the fast phase. Hence the answer will be Option B. The fast phase denotes the cortical correction and is more prominent.

Highyeild:

BASIC DEFINITIONS OF NYSTAGMUS Nystagmus is defined as regular and rhythmic to-and-fro involuntary oscillatory movements of the eyes. It may be characterised by any of the following features: Waveform : Pendular or jerk nystagmus. In pendular nystagmus movements are of equal velocity in each direction. It may be horizontal, vertical or rotatory. In jerk nystagmus , the movements have a slow component in one direction (defoveating movement, i.e. the movement that moves the fovea away from the object and a fast component in another direction (refoveating saccadic movement), i.e. the refixation movement that brings the object of interest back at fovea in the other direction. The direction of jerk nystagmus is defined by the direction of the fast component (phase). It may be right, left, up, down or rotatory. Direction of nystagmus may be horizontal, vertical, rotatory, torsional, oblique or a combination of these. Amplitude of nystagmus may be small, medium or large. Rate or frequency of nystagmus may be fast (rapid), or slow. Generally speaking faster the rate, the smaller the amplitude and vice versa. Conjugacy Nystagmus may be conjugate (symmetrical in both eyes), disconjugate (in different directions and different frequencies in two eyes) or dissociative ( unidirectional but asymmetrical). Manifest (present all the time) or latent (present only when one eye is covered).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. The direction is to the right side as the slow component is towards the right - This is not the correct option because the direction of the nystagmus is given by the fast phase Option: C. It can be on both sides - This is not the correct option because the direction of the nystagmus is given by the fast phase.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presented with decreased acuity in vision, and headache. Along with this he also has a sense of to and fro motion when actually he is not moving. During the examination of the patient, when his head is tilted to the right side the eyeball moves in the opposite direction. Which of the following phenomena is being referred to here?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vestibular-ocular reflex In the given question, the phenomena described as the movement of the eyeball in the opposite direction when the head is tilted to the other side is known as the vestibular-ocular reflex. If this mechanism is disturbed then it can also lead to nystagmus. Physiological vestibular nystagmus (vestibular-ocular reflex, i.e. VOH). It is a jerk nystagmus which can be elicited by stimulating the tympanic membrane with hot or cold water. It forms the basis of caloric tests . If cold water is poured into the right ear the patient develops left jerk nystagmus (rapid phase cowards left), while the reverse happens with warm water, i.e. patient develops right jerk nystagmus. lt can be remembered by the mnemonic 'COWS' ( Cold - Opposite, Warm-Same ).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Vestibular-acoustic reflex or simply acoustic reflex is the dampening of loud sound to prevent damage to the ear. Option: C .Oculo-cardiac reflex- it can occur during squint surgery when pressure applied over the EOM like MR can result in bradycardia.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presented with nystagmus in the right eye which is described as rapid, asymmetric small amplitude with torsional vertical nystagmus. A primary diagnosis of superior oblique myokymia was made. Which of the following treatments offered gives a dramatic response?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both A and B In the given question, the diagnosis of superior oblique myokymia is being made; it has nystagmus which is vertical torsional nystagmus. Rapid response is observed with carbamazepine or gabapentin. Hence the answer to this question is option D. Option C - Phenytoin does not have any role in the treatment.

Highyeild:

Superior oblique myokymia Superior oblique myokymia (SOM) is defined as "monocular, high-frequency, low-amplitude, torsional, and involuntary contractions of the superior oblique muscle that result in oscillopsia and diplopia." It is a monocular condition, first described by Duane in 1906 as "unilateral rotary nystagmus." It is thought that ephaptic transmission of impulses may be responsible for many of the cases seen with superior oblique myokymia. Triggers: patients will often associate the symptoms with stress, fatigue, nicotine, caffeine, and in one case, heat. In most patients, the symptoms are spontaneous. Medications : successful treatments have included topical beta-blockers, carbamazepine , baclofen, clonazepam, memantine, and mirtazapine.

questions.text: During your internship rotation in ophthalmology, you came across three different sets of patients with different kinds of nystagmus. They are as follows- 1. Patient A- 54-year-old male with weakness in the right half of the body with a diagnosis of stroke presented with adduction saccades. 2. Patient B- a 21-year-old male who on attempting up gaze presented with adduction and retraction of the eyeball. 3. Patient C- a 3-month-old child with Arnold Chiari malformation presented with nystagmus with a fast component in both eyes in the opposite direction away from the midline. Which of the following patient’s nystagmus described fits into the category of nystagmus retractorius?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Patient B In the given question, the presentation of patient B – correctly describes the nystagmus retractorius or the convergence retraction nystagmus. Convergence and retraction nystagmus : These are two special forms found with neurological damage localized to the upper mesencephalon . On attempted upgaze, the eyes display convergence-like movements accompanied by retraction of the globe . This occurs most commonly due to a pineal gland tumour or other midbrain abnormalities involving the aqueduct of Sylvius known as Parinaud syndrome or Sylvian aqueduct syndrome. In young patients, retraction nystagmus should suggest the diagnosis of midbrain glioma or pinealoma. The characteristic ocular features of the Sylvian aqueduct syndrome consist of the following: Retraction (and/or convergence) nystagmus Vertical nystagmus Difficult voluntary vertical gaze (especially upward gaze) Better vertical gaze on following or ‘doll’s-head movements’ than on command (with an intact Bell phenomenon) Adduction movements with attempted vertical gaze Defective convergence Retraction nystagmus with downgoing optokinetic targets Pupillary abnormalities (light-near dissociation) Pathological lid retraction

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Patient A description matches with convergence nystagmus in which only adduction is happening in both eyes. It can occur in patients with stroke, Whipple disease and Arnold Chiari malformation. Option: C . Patient C's presentation describes the divergent nystagmus in which both eyes move away from the midline. It is also associated with downbeat nystagmus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presented with arthralgia. He also says that abdominal pain and diarrhoea also occurred a few days back. Recently, he also complained of having malabsorption, and steatorrhea. The anti-TTG, anti endomysial Ab were also negative. The provisional diagnosis of Whipple's disease was made. Which of the following types of nystagmus is only associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oculo-masticatory myo-arrhythmia In the given question, in the patient with a provisional diagnosis of Whipple’s disease , the nystagmus only found in this condition is oculo-masticatory myo-arrhythmia .

Highyeild:

Oculomasticatory myorhythmia (OMM) is a pathognomonic manifestation of Whipple’s disease (WD) of the central nervous system . It is characterized by smooth, continuous, slow (1-3 Hz), pendular, convergent-divergent nystagmus, concurrent contractions of the masticatory muscles , supranuclear vertical gaze palsy, and occasionally, rhythmic movements of the limbs. It differs from other forms of pendular nystagmus in that it is smooth and continuous with a high amplitude and slow frequency . These eye movements may persist during sleep. Pathogenesis & Epidemiology Whipple’s disease is a rare systemic disorder that primarily affects the gastrointestinal system causing malabsorption , although it can affect any part of the body. It often presents with symptoms of weight loss, steatorrhea, arthralgia, fever, and sometimes, neurologic findings like dementia and somnolence . It is caused by the bacteria Tropheryma whipplei which predominantly infects macrophages of the small intestines. The specific findings of OMM are thought to be due to lesions in the midbrain and upper pons Definite CNS WD Must have any 1 of the following 3 criteria: OMM or OFSM Positive tissue biopsy Positive PCR analysis Treatment It has been shown that the most efficient treatment may be with doxycycline and hydroxychloroquine. Another generally accepted treatment regimen for WD with OMM or OFSM is daily IV ceftriaxone or penicillin G for two weeks, followed by TMP-SMX twice a day for a year. However, chloramphenicol, TMP-SMX, tetracycline, erythromycin, and ceftriaxone are all antibiotics that can cross the blood-brain-barrier and have been found to be effective in WD with CNS manifestations

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Convergence nystagmus can also be seen in these patients but can also be associated with other conditions like Arnold Chiari malformation, and Option : B. Divergence nystagmus is not seen in Whipple’s It can occur in cases with Arnold Chiari malformation

questions.text: A 48-year-old male who is a known case of hypertensive is on tablet amlodipine and telmisartan for its management. He also is a known case of mania and is currently maintained on lithium. His serum lithium concentration is 0.7mEq/L. He came to the emergency with repetitive rapid eye movement in both eyes in the left direction which became more prominent when looking to the left with his face straight. Which of the following can be the offending drug that the patient is taking?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lithium In the given question, the patient is on antihypertensive and mood stabilizer drugs. But the nystagmus which is occurring in this patient is most commonly due to lithium . This is known as drug-induced Drug-induced nystagmus is mainly symmetric, binocular conjugate spontaneous jerk, predominantly horizontal movements. They are most often seen with tranquil l izing or anticonvulsant medication . Most often they are evident with an eccentric gaze. Hence the correct answer is option B.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Antihypertensive medications like amlodipine or telmisartan are not associated with nystagmus. Hence options A and C are not correct.
